docs.lead_paragraph: John J. Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. president, issued a defiant ''make my day'' declaration today to Republicans in Congress who want revenge on the labor movement for its pull-out-the-stops drive to defeat them in last fall's elections. ''We're going to resist and oppose any efforts that are made toward recriminations for any of the good work we did last year,'' Mr. Sweeney said at a news conference on the first day of the federation's winter meeting here. ''If there is going to be any attempt at retribution, we'll be as out front as we have been on any other issue.''

headline.main: Labor Dares Republicans To Cut Its Political Clout

docs.abstract: AFL-CIO president John J Sweeney issues defiant declaration to Congressional Republicans seeking revenge on labor movement for drive to defeat them in fall 1996 general elections, speech to federation's winter meeting in Los Angeles; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Sally Rowe decided to take a semester off from the College of Charleston in South Carolina to ski and work in Colorado, she was losing more than a few months of school. She also lost her health insurance. Ms. Rowe, 21, had been covered under her parents' policy, but only as long as she was a full-time student. When she put on her skis, she suddenly became an independent adult, responsible for her own health care. And the restaurant where she has taken a part-time job doesn't offer coverage. Worse, she didn't realize any of this and was about to go hurtling down the mountains around Boulder with absolutely no health insurance.

headline.main: Putting Aside the Books But Keeping Insurance

docs.abstract: Many college students give little thought to health insurance mainly because coverage has always been there when they needed it, provided either through their parents or through their colleges; American College Health Assn, grade group, Baltimore, estimates that 11 percent of college students have no health insurance, and experts say those covered through their schools may not realize just how little coverage they have; about third of college students are covered under their parents' plans, and slighly more buy coverage through their schools; problems students face when they leave school noted; photo; chart on coverage (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Even though new drugs show great promise in combating AIDS, many patients are finding that they cannot easily get the costly medicines because of restrictions imposed by health maintenance organizations and by state programs set up to assist people with low incomes. Some H.M.O.'s say they limit pharmacy benefits to a specified amount -- $3,000 a year a patient is typical.

headline.main: Expense Means Many Can't Get Drugs for AIDS

docs.abstract: Even though new drugs show great promise in combating AIDS, many patients are finding they cannot easily get costly medicines because of restrictions imposed by health maintenance organizations and by state programs set up to assist people with low incomes; HMO's limit pharmacy benefits to typically $3,000 per patient annually, or far less than cost of drug combinations often recommended by doctors; regimens, some of which combine new protease inhibitor drugs with older antiviral medications, can easily cost $10,000 to $15,000 per year; shortcomings of drug assistance programs in Missouri, Colo, Ill, Fla, Washington State, New York and elsewhere discussed (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Bernard Hyman founded the law firm of Certilman Balin Adler & Hyman in 1965, the practice concentrated primarily on real-estate law and thrived on the building boom that had enveloped Long Island -- housing complexes and shopping centers. But the real-estate market hit the skids in the 80's. And with the advent of no-fault in automobile accident cases and equitable sharing of property in divorce cases, the need for lawyers in those areas declined.

headline.main: Facing New Challenges, Law Firms Diversify

docs.abstract: Law firms on Long Island, many of whom prospered for years by focusing on now-defunct real estate boom, are diversifying and recruiting lawyers with other specialties in order to stay competitive; list of major Long Island firms; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE nervousness over stocks is palpable in the personal-finance magazines for March. Much of the boundless optimism at the end of last year has turned to caution and sweaty-palm advice on how to weather a market downturn. Never mind that, despite some stumbles, the market is off to a fast start this year. A consensus seems to be building that some sort of correction is in order. Whether this opinion reflects reality or turns out to be a self-fulfilling prophecy doesn't much matter. Down is down. But wrong is also wrong, which is what conventional wisdom sometimes is. The dice are rolling. Place your bets.

headline.main: By These Compasses, the Market May Be Turning South

docs.abstract: Personal finance magazines, which expressed boundless optimist at end of last year, have turned to caution on how to weather a market downturn; consensus seems to be building that some sort of correction is in order; advice offered to investors by some magazines noted; photos (M)'

docs.lead_paragraph: Two years ago, soon after he took charge of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, Arthur F. Ryan took what might seem to be an unusual step for a chairman. He encouraged New Jersey's insurance commissioner to investigate the company. Mr. Ryan wanted New Jersey to take the lead in investigating complaints filed by thousands of longtime Prudential customers across the nation. At least six states were examining the allegations that the company's agents had deceived customers into buying new, more expensive life insurance policies solely to earn sales commissions. But New Jersey, Prudential's home state, was not among them.

headline.main: How a State Regulated a Hand That Feeds It
headline.kicker: THE EYE ON PRUDENTIAL: A special report.

docs.abstract: Special report, The Eye On Prudential, examines criticisms of probe of Prudential Insurance Company of America by New Jersey regulators at company's request, following complaints by thousands of customers; at heart of criticism is question of whether home-state regulators went too far in protecting company, third-largest private employer in New Jersey, at expense of millions of policyholders; year-long inquiry by state-led team of examiners found widespread abuses by Prudential agents that management should have known of as early as 1992; fined company $35 million and ordered it to sign settlement to pay at least $410 million, and possibly $1 billion, to wronged policyholders; regulators in other states and lawyers for thousands of customers have challenged settlement; say fine amounts to little more than pittance for company with assets of $219 billion; cite fundamental flaws in task force inquiry; note: most customers who lost money may never get it back since settlement puts most of burden of proof on them; photos (L)
